title: Isador Coriat
text:
Isador Henry Coriat (December 10, 1875 – May 26, 1943) was an American psychiatrist and neurologist of <a href="Moroccan%20Jews">Moroccan-Jewish</a> descent. He was one of the first American psychoanalysts.
Biography.
He was born in Philadelphia in 1875 as the son of Harry (Hyram) Coriat, a <a href="Moroccan%20Jews">Moroccan Jew</a> native of <a href="Marrakesh">Marrakesh</a>, who emigrated to the United States from France in 1867, and Clara née Einstein. He was of Moroccan Jewish descent on father's side and German on mother's side. He grew up in <a href="Boston">Boston</a> and attended <a href="Tufts%20University%20School%20of%20Medicine">Tufts Medical School</a>, graduating in 1900.
He was one of the founders of <a href="Boston%20Psychoanalytic%20Society">Boston Psychoanalytic Society</a>, the first secretary in 1914 and president in years 1930–32. Coriat was the only Freudian analyst in Boston during the period after <a href="James%20Jackson%20Putnam">James Jackson Putnam</a>'s death.
Coriat worked with the Rev. <a href="Elwood%20Worcester">Elwood Worcester</a>, served as the medical expert for the <a href="Emmanuel%20Movement">Emmanuel Movement</a> and co-authored "Religion and Medicine; The Moral Control of Nervous Disorders".
Coriat married Etta Dann in 1910. He died on May 26, 1943, after a brief illness.
